ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Recorded and live virtual lectures
Live weekly discussion sections with required attendance
section
Discussion section
Virtual discussion sections
Weekly sections, test review sessions
It was a combination of recorded lectures, live virtual lectures and live discussion sections which gave me many options to choose what was best for me during the course.
Section

- Recorded lectures
-
Live in-person discussions within discussion sections.
Recorded Lecture
Live discussion sections
Mainly virtual lecture with virtual discussion section.
Live virtual lecture and recorded lecture
I occasionally was not able to make the live lecture, and would watch the recorded lecture instead. I found the flexibility to choose extremely helpful in this very unusual semester.
recorded lecture and virtual discussion section
None
Discussion section every week too
There was also live virtual sections.
All of the readings were also helpful to grasp concepts from the lectures.
Live virtual lectures demanded synchronous attendance, but were also recorded and available to be rewatched under Media Library on Canvas.
live virtual lecture that was recorded and posted to Canvas; synchronous live virtual section 1x a week
Sometimes I would watch the recorded lecture
Lectures were also recorded in addition to live zooms
discussion section over zoom
Discussion section
There were live virtual lectures as well as discussion sections

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic knowledge of conservation biology.
Different facets of conservation biology and the challenges that hinder its progress.

I was able to learn a lot more about conservation biology, though a lot of the material in the first half of the course was preliminary AP Environmental Science information. Afterwards, I learned a lot more about applications of the specific biology concepts. The course helped teach me how to read scientific writing, as well as analyzing it and discussing it with peers.
I studied a basic overview of conservation biology, which touched on a pretty broad range of topics including evolution and climate change.
I leaned a lot about the context of conservation biology in public spheres

I got a very good general overview of important conservation biology issues -- what does conservation biology mean? why is it important to protect biodiversity? how to these issues intersect with political and economics considerations? what are the general sorts of conservation strategies, etc.

I developed important time management skills and learned how to best study for this type of class. I also learned the importance of doing the outside readings and how closely they relate to the class.
I gained a plethora of information about conserving the environment and what goes into it.

Through this course, I developed a strong overview of knowledge about conservation biology on both the micro and macro scale. In the course, you focus both on the biological side, evaluate case studies, and focus on current threats to biodiversity. Really interesting material.
I learned about the modern techniques for conservation efforts on the global and local scale.
An understanding of conservation biology and its applications to conservation design.
A good understanding of the basics of conservation biology.
I learned a broad basis of conservation biology as well as its real-world applications. I learned A LOT during this course.
As a non-science major, I felt like I became a lot more comfortable reading about and discussing scientific issues related to conservation and climate change.

Ability to summarise key research points from journal articles
Debate skills considering multiple view points
Basics of conservation biology including theory, methods and purpose
Real world applications through research presentations and case studies
I gained a better understanding of the biodiversity on earth and how my personal actions affect it.
Learnt about conservation bio, models used in the field and the impacts of COVID-19 on biodiversity
Developed a general understanding of conservation biology. Skills to reading scientific papers.
I learned the many impacts human actions have on the environment, and many ways in which conservation biology can mitigate these impacts.
I learned about what conservation biology is and what it does. We learned about the causes and consequences of the decline in biodiversity and also how efforts are being made to counter this loss.
I learned how to efficiently read and synthesize actual scientific papers and obviously a bunch of environmental stuff pertinent to the class

This course gave me a great comprehensive overview of the current efforts of conservation biology. We discussed threats to natural habits and touched extensively on climate change. I enjoyed how accessible the material was as a non science major.
reading scientific papers, biological inquiry, understanding relationships between biological concepts on a large scale
I learned a fundamental foundation for ecological studies, as well as methods to attempt to conserve regions based on a wide variety of thought.

I think a lot of the learning in this class is extremely intuitive, especially if you've previously taken environmental science classes or are engaged in environmentalism, which was a bit disappointing and often made class a bit boring. However, some of the neat things that I managed to pick up on due to the course's focus on conservation mainly included the ways conservation biologists categorize and assist/repair species and habitats, including specific techniques and approaches. I enjoyed the ethical insights we also looked at and weighed with each of the possible options/routes as well. I think the course excelled when it looked at specific case studies. Although Professor Puth tied examples into all her lectures, we focused on a couple of case studies during the semester (devoting whole lectures to certain places) that were really interesting and engaging.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - clear, methodical lectures
Weaknesses - some of the assignments lacked detail initially, but all questions were quickly answered

Strengths- good mix of assignments; broad overview of the field; readings were varied and interesting. 
Weaknesses- at least in the beginning, many of us felt the exams were too long for time allotted; sometimes exam questions did not directly relate to what we learned in class.

The lecture itself was very minimally interactive and could be difficult to pay attention to, but the discussion section entailed a large amount of participation, which helped make the class more interesting. The exams were much more difficult than the material presented in class, meaning that they were confusing at points.

The course provided a broad range of generally interesting assignments, which was good. In terms of topics covered, it felt like we were given an extremely broad overview of many different things such that I feel as if I have not learned much about any specific thing. It might be helpful in the future to go a bit more in-depth on a few topics. Even though this is an introductory course, I feel that it could benefit from being slightly less elementary.

Strengths: discussion sections were very helpful 
Weaknesses: too many big assignments

strengths: Professor Puth and all the TA's are phenomenal. And this course has some of the best-structured tests I've ever taken. They did a very good job making sure that test questions left room for our own creativity re: conservation strategies while making sure we incorporated the big ideas of each unit. Creative assignments like the debate also helped. The writing assignments were good alternatives to labs, for example, for a non-stem major like me. 

weaknesses: none I can think of. great course

This course had many interesting and engaging assignments outside of the class time, which I enjoyed. However, there was also a lot of work outside of the class (especially with readings), and I found them difficult to complete in time for class.
strengths: material is clearly taught and is made relevant by the professor. weakness: some what difficult to test because the material is very idea focused.

Strengths: 
Great professor
Great content and engagement

Weaknesses: 
Questions a bit ambiguous at times

Overall, the course was structured pretty well with the combination of lectures and the discussion sections. I think that the zoom recordings of the lectures allowed students to be able to fit it in with their own schedule, especially when accounting for the weirdness of this zoom year. Overall, the structure of the course was strong, and the assignments made sense. I think it would be beneficial to restructure the scheduling of the position piece and debate, as these two assignments were too close to each other considering their importance.
Lectures were sometimes disorganized but the content was relatively easy to master.
I felt really engaged in discussion sections as well as lectures

I think this course was very strong at making scientific concepts accessible to non-science majors. I thought the guest lecture, outside lecture assignment and talks from the TAs were wonderful additions to the usual lectures. I also thought the discussion sections were extremely engaging; more so than many discussion sections I've been a part of in previous semesters.
Understandable progression through syllabus. Enjoyed the variety of assignments so that they weren't all written essays.  Exams were of enjoyable difficulty and graded quickly.
The online format became redundant and boring, but that is not the instructor's fault.
Strengths were the debate and discussion section.  Weakness is that every lecture felt as if it was being read off the lecture slides.
Lectures were well formatted, sections could have been more structured.

Strengths: Clear delivery of information, necessary for learning about conservation biology. A good introduction to other ecology classes.

Negatives: The format felt too similar throughout the virtual lectures. I wish there was more variation in the lectures.

Standard science credit. Not a particularly exciting class, but it fulfills the distributional requirement. Exams and exam grading were fair. Non-exam assignment grading seemed random, and there was no clear process to request regrades.
Discussion section seemed to drag on for a bit longer than it needed to be.
the exams were not written that well and there was not a realistic amount of time given for them

This class is a lot of work. At some point, we had a few major assignments (debate, midterm, paper) stacked within a week, and it felt like I was using disproportionate time on this class compared to others. The three exams were also (not necessarily difficult but) somewhat tediously long for how much time we were given (4+ parts to 7+ writing questions each time). Overall it felt like I had to give this course a lot more time and work than my other courses.

I'm not saying that this class was a piece of cake... but I do feel like a lot of the material in the lecture was very common sense-oriented, and yet the tests were much more applied and required making that intellectual jump that wasn't really pushed in class.
The units were arranged well and I really enjoyed the readings. Sometimes I feel like lectures were slightly rushed.
Discussion section with Gillian was especially helpful. Grading was fair and feedback was thorough. Weekly readings were interesting and relevant to the course.
I felt the course was quite strong in its presentation.

Strengths included some wonderful TAs and very organized lectures and assignment schedules. Weaknesses included unclear exam expectations and assignments/readings that often felt like busy work (specifically the weekly research papers!). These research papers were supposed to showcase examples of what we were studying, but almost always felt very superfluous and unnecessary, especially since it ate into the time we would otherwise use in section to go over concepts from class and prepare for future exams, etc. I also would have liked to see Professor Puth engage more with students during class, like asking more questions or making the lectures a bit more interactive. although I'm certain this was made more difficult due to the transition to virtual.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Synchronous discussion sections were very helpful. I also liked how we could take exams within a 24/48 hour period to account for time differences.
Virtual learning made it difficult to remain engaged in the course.
The recorded lectures were good; discussion sections worked well, etc. Overall, great use of virtual tools available.
Professor Puth was very lenient and helpful for COVID learning. Flexibility of deadlines was very helpful
The professor and teaching assistants were very accommodating!
All-around successful, all the teaching staff made themselves super available and the recorded lectures and review sessions were so key

Everything went about as smoothly as they could have gone, given that it was completely virtual. I liked that the lectures were recorded so I could go back and rewatch lectures to be sure I understood the information. And open notes tests were really great for me because it would have been too much to memorize every concept.
I think the class functioned similarly to a regular lecture and section formatted class.

This course succeeded when considering COVID. The lectures and the discussion sections worked well with people's schedules, and professor Puth was extremely accommodating with deadlines, especially when it came to testing structure.
breakout rooms worked great
Discussion section was great, lectures were sometimes challenging to focus in  but Professor Puth would have breakout rooms which helped students stay engaged.
A little more time could have been allotted in exams 1 and 2, as learning environments are different.

I thought that the workload for this course was a little bit unreasonable for the semester, and could occasionally be hard to manage between going to lecture, section, doing reading & reading responses, essays, the debate, etc. I think that it would have been easier to engage with the course more deeply if we had 1 or 2 fewer assignments. I found myself significantly more stressed about all of the work in this class than in most of my other classes. I did appreciate the extension on the position paper, I think it was very needed.
Lectures were good. Maybe requiring videos to be on would have increased engagement.

Succeeded: Amazing teaching fellows that responded quickly to emails and helpful during section. Quick responses from all teachers.

Could be improved: Not sure.

Having so many deadlines for papers and exams during a pandemic was stressful and did not seem to take into account how mentally and physically fatiguing learning can be when one is also dealing with a series of mental, financial, academic, and personal health tolls.
Section zooms weren't super organized but our TA was cool and we still managed to be semi-productive.
Having the live zoom, plus the recorded lectures were helpful.
Course was well suited for remote learning
The Professor was incredibly understanding with circumstances regarding COVID-19 and the pandemic.

Professor Puth recorded her lectures but asked everyone to attend her Zooms synchronously. Although I think this was a good idea, it would have made more sense if there were more interaction/engagement in the lecture. However, most did not involve any, and as such could have been entirely asynchronous.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I took it for the science credit and found it interesting and not overly challenging.
Yes, great interdisciplinary class for anybody who likes animals

Yes, particularly for non-STEM majors. The material was, for the most part, accessible regardless of previous knowledge and very pertinent to our everyday lives (e.g. the discussions about the impact of climate change).

Yes. It provides a good introduction into conservation biology and Professor Puth and the TFs were well-informed and knowledgeable. Online, the course was not too engaging, but the material itself, as well as the debate, made it worth it.

If you're looking for a somewhat interesting, relatively easy science credit, this course is a pretty good choice. The topics covered are very relevant. However, the course did seem extremely elementary in terms of content and pace, and there are other non-major science courses at Yale that you can take for SC credit that teach you something much more in-depth. This course gave a decent, (very) broad overview of conservation biology though. It was also very easy to do well given the large number of assignments.
Yes! It was a good Science credit that felt relevant and manageable.
absolutely would recommend, especially to plsc majors -- this course is a great overview of issues that are important to political debates, like the Dakota Access Pipeline or Bristol Bay mine.

Yes, I would recommend this class, especially for non-science majors because it is very interesting and relevant, but you do not need to be super invested in the material as a career or have any prerequisites.
Yes, I believe Professor Puth is a great teacher and her class is very informative.
Yes, 100%. Really interesting and pertinent material paired with an easier class workload.
Yes.
Yes, its very manageable to do well.
Yes! Very well taught and informative class, never too easy but also not too difficult for a non-STEM major.

Yes! This course is great for anyone interested in conservation or sustainability and is definitely accesible to students who are not science majors. The workload is manageable, and the professors and TFs are all very knowledgable, helpful, and caring!
Yes! Definitely take the class if you have an interest in biodiversity conservation (be it from a science, policy, management or economic standpoint)
Yes! It's a good science credit for non-science majors.
Yes! Very much so
Yes! I would definitely recommend this to non-science majors who need an SC credit or to underclassmen thinking about E&EB.
Yes, great as a SC credit for non-majors, but I enjoyed it as a less strenuous introduction to the field alongside more considerable workload courses.
Yes, I think it is incredibly valuable to have an understanding of the world's biodiversity.
Yes, a good science credit for a non-STEM major. Interesting connections can be made with other fields of study.
Yes, I would recommend to a student who is interested in studying environmental studies or ecology for a basic introduction.

Take it if you need the science credit. It's not a complete gut, but it's not super difficult either. The class is honestly kind of boring. But you'll be hard-pressed to find a science credit (for non-science majors) with actually interesting and engaging course content. Most difficult part of the class for me was sitting through discussion section each week, listening to some rote variation of "humans are bad for the environment and here's why!" or "we should all be vegans." 

Exams were fair and tested concepts covered in lecture. The non-exam assignment grading was honestly ridiculous at times, and grades on these assignments seemed to depend significantly on the whims and personality of your assigned TF. The professor clearly knows what she's talking about, her lectures were clear, and she was very nice and understanding throughout the semester. 

As science credits go, this isn't a bad one to take if you have few other options. I mean, what else is there to take? Plants and People?
I'd recommend this to a student that might not be a biology major, but is still interested in environmental biology.
Yes- pretty interesting material, really solid instructor, won't kill you with the work load.
Yes! I have already recommended this course to various non science majors because the material is important for everyone to have a baseline understanding.
Yes. This course provides a general overview of ecology and evolutionary biology without being too technical. Grading is fair and there are numerous resources available to help with studying.
Absolutely.

If you're interested in environmentalism and conservation, then sure, but know that it might not be as comprehensive or novel as you may want. The concepts were not difficult and the reading loads were pretty light most weeks, but also don't expect the class to be a breeze, since the examinations were very challenging and there was also a fair amount of other assignments & busywork.
